project.teaser: The development of the bioeconomy holds great potential for driving growth in a sustainable manner. Still, many European regions have yet to unlock this potential, despite considerable investments in research, innovation and business support. In this context, MainstreamBIO...
project.objective: The development of the bioeconomy holds great potential for driving growth in a sustainable manner. Still, many European regions have yet to unlock this potential, despite considerable investments in research, innovation and business support. In this context, MainstreamBIO sets out to get small-scale bio-based solutions into mainstream practice across rural Europe, providing a broader range of rural actors with the opportunity to engage in and speed up the development of the bioeconomy. We start with regional Multi-actor Innovation Platforms (MIPs) established in 7 EU countries (PL, DK, SE, BG, ES, IE and NL) to enhance cooperation among key rural players towards co-creating sustainable business model pathways in line with regional potentials and policy initiatives. Alongside them we support 35 multi-actor partnerships to overcome barriers and get bio-based innovations to market with hands-on innovation support, accelerating the development of over 70 marketable bio-based products and services. In parallel, we develop and employ a digital toolkit to better match bio-based technologies, social innovations and good nutrient recycling practices with available biomass and market trends as well as to enhance understanding of the bioeconomy with a suite of educational resources building on existing research results and tools. Along the way, a monitoring and evaluation framework will gauge the performance and impact of our measures, providing us with the intel required to catalyse mutual learning across regions and contribute to the creation of policy frameworks more conducive to the uptake of small-scale bio-based solutions in rural areas. In the process, we cluster with relevant initiatives and offer tools to facilitate the replication of our results, ensuring their long-term sustainability as viable solutions for supporting the growth of local inclusive and circular bioeconomies in other rural areas, that can ultimately link to form a strong EU‑wide circular bioeconomy.
project.title: MAINSTREAMing small-scale BIO-based solutions across rural Europe via regional Multi-actor Innovation Platforms and tailored innovation support
project.keywords: Small-scale bio-based solutions, nutrient recycling, scale-up, innovation support services, sustainable rural development, multi-actor innovation platforms, social innovation

article.title: Innovative, small-scale bio-based solutions for rural Europe

result.title: Exploitation and Sustainability Plan - initial version
result.description: A report produced under T5.3 and T5.4 defining the strategy and methodology of MainstreamBIO with respect to innovation and IPR management (Q-PLAN). The report will also outline plans and provisions for paving the way towards the smooth post-project exploitation and sustainability of the project’s assets (Q-PLAN), as well as it will present the initial business model and plan of MainstreamBIO (INNV).

result.title: MainstreamBIO Multi-actor Innovation Platforms
result.description: A report outlining the findings of the mapping exercise and the activities related to the formation of the MIPs, as well as their baseline operational model conducted during T1.1.

result.title: Dissemination and Communication Plan and Activities - initial version
result.description: A report elaborating on the strategy, plan, and actions to be undertaken under T5.1 with respect to dissemination and communication activities of the project. The report will also include specific qualitative and quantitative targets to be met by the respective activities of the project throughout its course.

result.title: From Strategy to Action for a Regional, Participatory, and Sustainable EU Bioeconomy

details.authors: Sara Altamore|APRE; Holger Gerdes|Ecologic Institute; Zoritza Kiresiewa|Ecologic Institute; Bas Paris|CERTH; Magdalena Borzęcka|IUNG; Stelios Rozakis|Technical University of Crete; Anastasios Galatsopoulos|White Research; Leonidas Parodos|Q-PLAN

result.title: Data Management Plan - interim version
result.description: The updated version of the Data Management Plan. This version will build upon and update D6.2 to reflect any newly identified data that were collected / generated during the project as well as any changes in data previously identified and/or the methodology and plans of MainstreamBIO for sound and FAIR data management.

result.title: Understanding the biomass availability, flows and value chains of diverse rural regions in Europe
Dissemination and Communication Plan and Activities - interim version
result.description: The updated version of D5.1 fine-tuning as appropriate the strategy, plan and actions to be undertaken under T5.1 with respect to dissemination and communication activities of the project. The report will also update, if necessary, the targets to be met by the respective activities of the project throughout its course.

result.title: Data Management Plan - first version
result.description: A report produced under T6.3. The report will outline the data to be collected / generated during the project as well as the data management methodology and plan to be followed across their life cycle in order to ensure their sound and FAIR management in line with applicable legislation at national and EU level.

result.title: Management and Quality Plan
result.description: A report produced in T6.1 outlining MainstreamBIO’s management structure, the roles and responsibilities of partners as well as the procedures for progress monitoring, quality assurance and project management. The report will also include a Gantt chart and a Work Breakdown Structure (WBS) along with a schedule per task, related deliverables, and dependencies on other tasks as well as any responsible partner related subtasks.

result.title: Policy insights
result.description: A short report under Task 4.4 providing initial policy insights to facilitate the application of small-scale bio-based solutions in rural areas, based on results of analysis of current situation (under WP1), co-creation activities under Task 2.3 and desk research.

result.title: Report on context and needs of rural stakeholders
result.description: A report presenting the objectives, methodology and findings of the analysis conducted under T1.2. The report will profile each MIP focal region, synthetising the knowledge gained on farmers’ needs, perceptions and socio-economic contexts and framework conditions.

result.title: Practice abstracts - Batch 1
result.description: This deliverable contains 10 practice abstracts, including the first batch of the MainstreamBIO material produced in the form of summaries for practitioners in the EIP common format, developed under T4.5.

result.title: From local innovations to global markets in the forestry bioeconomy
Mapping of regional bio-based value chains
result.description: A report presenting the objectives, methodology and findings of the investigation of regional value chains conducted under T1.3. The report will present a mapping of the available biomass feedstocks, waste and residue streams, actors, processes, resource flows, and bioeconomy value chains in the project’s focal regions.

result.title: MainstreamBIO innovation support services - initial version
result.description: A report that will describe the initial version of the features, functions, and material required for the delivery of the MainstreamBIO innovation support services by the MIPs based on the outcomes of the co-creation workshop and the activities of T2.3.

result.title: Best practices for improved nutrient recycling
result.description: This report will outline the collection of best practices for improved nutrient recycling in the circular bioeconomy, complemented by the insights collected from the in-depth interviews and the pertinent activities under T2.2.

result.title: Small-scale bio-based solutions promoting the regional development of bioeconomy
Catalogue of small-scale bio-based technologies, business models and social innovations
result.description: A report presenting the outcomes of the bibliographic review of small-scale bio-based technologies, social innovations and business models under T2.1.

result.title: Research to Impact Showcase event

details.journalTitle: Understanding the biomass availability, flows and value chains of diverse rural regions in Europe.

category.title: recycling
category.displayCode: /engineering and technology/environmental engineering/waste management/waste treatment processes/recycling

category.title: Digital agenda
category.description: This tracker monitors Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to the development of digital technologies and the digitisation of the economy and society (known as ‘Digital transition’).

category.title: Clean air
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to the clean air policy (National Emission Ceiling Directive) aiming to improve ambient air quality and tackle air pollution, to protect the environment and human health.

category.title: Artificial intelligence
category.description: This tracker monitors Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to the development and deployment of AI-based technologies and solutions. Projects that develop AI-tools as part of their research method are included

category.title: Climate action
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to both mitigating climate change (e.g., contributions to the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions) and adapting to climate change by building resilience (e.g., regarding floods, droughts, spatial planning and better governance, adaptation to changing climate in value chains, etc.).

category.title: Biodiversity
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to Europe’s biodiversity’s path to recovery including species protection, ecosystem conservation, and habitat rehabilitation, all essential for resilience in climate adaptation and addressing ecosystem services but also environmental crime and the health-environment connection.
